12.verse: So Manoah asked, “When what you say happens, what kind of life should the boy live? What ·should he do [is his mission/vocation]?”

13.verse: The ·angel [messenger] of the LORD said, “Your wife must be careful to do everything I told her to do.

14.verse: She must not eat anything that grows on a grapevine, or drink any wine or ·beer [or other fermented drink; strong drink; v. 4], or eat anything that is unclean [in a ritual sense]. She must do everything I have commanded her.”

15.verse: Manoah said to the ·angel [messenger] of the LORD, “We would like you to stay awhile so we can cook a young goat for you.”

16.verse: The ·angel [messenger] of the LORD answered, “Even if I stay awhile, I would not eat your food. But if you want to prepare something, offer a burnt offering [Lev. 1:1–17] to the LORD.” (Manoah did not understand that the man was really the ·angel [messenger] of the LORD.)

17.verse: Then Manoah asked the ·angel [messenger] of the LORD, “What is your name? Then we will honor you when what you have said really happens.”

18.verse: The ·angel [messenger] of the LORD said, “Why do you ask my name? It is ·too amazing for you to understand [beyond comprehension; wonderful; Is. 9:6].”

19.verse: So Manoah sacrificed a young goat on a rock and offered ·some grain as a gift [a grain/gift/tribute offering; Lev. 2:1] to the LORD. Then ·an amazing thing happened [or the LORD did an amazing thing] as Manoah and his wife watched.

20.verse: As the flames went up to ·the sky [heaven] from the altar, the ·angel [messenger] of the LORD ·went up [ascended] in the flame. When Manoah and his wife saw that, they bowed facedown on the ground.

21.verse: The ·angel [messenger] of the LORD did not appear to them again. Then Manoah ·understood [realized; knew] that the man was really the ·angel [messenger] of the LORD.

22.verse: Manoah said, “We have seen ·God [or a divine being; Hebrew: Elohim; v. 3], so we will surely die [6:23; Gen. 16:13].”

23.verse: But his wife said to him, “If the LORD wanted to kill us, he would not have accepted our burnt offering [Lev. 1:1–17] or ·grain [gift; tribute] offering [Lev. 2:1]. He would not have shown us all these things or told us all this.”

24.verse: So the woman gave birth to a boy and named him Samson [related to the Hebrew word for “sun”; perhaps “sun-like” or “light from God”; Mal. 4:2]. He grew, and the LORD blessed him.

25.verse: The Spirit of the LORD began to ·work in Samson [move/stir/empower him] while he was in the city of Mahaneh Dan, between the cities of Zorah and Eshtaol.

1.verse: Samson’s First Marriage - Samson went down to the city of Timnah where he saw ·a Philistine woman [one of the daughters of the Philistines].

2.verse: When he returned home, he said to his father and mother, “I saw ·a Philistine woman [one of the daughers of the Philistines] in Timnah. I want you to get her for me so I can marry her.”

3.verse: His father and mother answered, “·Surely there is [Is there not…?] a woman from ·Israel [the daughters of your brothers/relatives] you can marry. Do you have to marry a woman from the uncircumcised Philistines [Deut. 7:1–3]?” But Samson said, “Get that woman for me! She is ·the one I want [right in my eyes]!”

4.verse: (Samson’s parents did not know that ·the LORD wanted this to happen [this was from the LORD] because he was looking for a ·way [opportunity] to challenge the Philistines, who were ruling over Israel at this time.)

5.verse: Samson went down with his father and mother to Timnah, as far as the vineyard near there. ·Suddenly [And behold], a young lion came roaring toward Samson!

6.verse: The Spirit of the LORD ·entered Samson with great power [empowered/came upon/rushed upon him; 3:10; 6:34; 11:29], and he tore the lion apart with his bare hands. ·For him it was as easy as tearing apart […as one tears] a young goat. But Samson did not tell his father or mother what he had done.

7.verse: Then he went down to the city and talked to the Philistine woman, and ·he liked her [she was right in Samson’s eyes].

8.verse: Several days later Samson went back to ·marry [get; take] her. On his way he went over to look at the body of the dead lion and ·found [behold, there was] a swarm of bees and honey in it.

9.verse: Samson ·got [scooped; scraped] some of the honey with his hands and walked along eating it. When he came to his parents, he gave some to them. They ate it, too, but Samson did not tell them he had ·taken [scooped; scraped] the honey from the body of the dead lion [touching the carcass violated Samson’s Nazirite vow; 13:5, 7; Num. 6:6].

10.verse: Samson’s father went down to see the Philistine woman. And Samson gave a feast, as was the custom for the ·bridegroom [young men].

11.verse: When the people saw him, they sent thirty ·friends [companions; groomsmen] to be with him.

12.verse: Samson’s Riddle - Samson said to them, “Let me tell you a riddle. Try to find the answer during the seven days of the feast. If you can, I will give you thirty linen ·shirts [garments] and thirty changes of clothes.

13.verse: But if you can’t, you must give me thirty linen ·shirts [garments] and thirty changes of clothes.” So they said, “Tell us your riddle so we can hear it.”

14.verse: Samson said, “Out of the eater comes something to eat. Out of the strong comes something sweet.” After three days, they had not ·found the answer [solved the riddle].

15.verse: On the fourth day they said to Samson’s wife, “Did you invite us here to make us poor? ·Trick [Entice; Coax] your husband into telling us the answer to the riddle. If you don’t, we will burn you and everyone in your father’s house.”

16.verse: So Samson’s wife went to him, crying, and said, “You hate me! You don’t really love me! You told ·my people [the sons of my people] a riddle, but you won’t tell me the answer.” Samson said, “I haven’t even told my father or mother. Why should I tell you?”

17.verse: Samson’s wife cried for the rest of the seven days of the feast. So he finally gave her the answer on the seventh day, because she kept ·bothering [nagging; pressing] him. Then she told ·her [the sons of her] people the answer to the riddle.

18.verse: Before sunset on the seventh day of the feast, the Philistine men had the answer. They came to Samson and said, “What is sweeter than honey? What is stronger than a lion?” Then Samson said to them, “If you had not plowed with my ·young cow [heifer; referring to his wife], you would not have solved my riddle!”

19.verse: Then the Spirit of the LORD ·entered Samson and gave him great power [empowered/came upon/rushed upon him; v. 6]. Samson went down to the city of Ashkelon [a Philistine capital] and killed thirty of its men and took all that they had and gave the clothes to the men who had answered his riddle. Then he went to his father’s house very angry.

20.verse: And Samson’s wife was given to his best man [one of those companions who had attended the feast].

1.verse: Samson Troubles the Philistines - At the time of the wheat harvest [late May or early June], Samson went to visit his wife, taking a young goat with him [as a gift]. He said, “I’m going to my wife’s room,” but her father would not let him go in.

2.verse: He said to Samson, “I thought you really hated your wife, so I gave her to your ·best man [companion; 14:20]. ·Her younger sister is [Is not her younger sister…?] more beautiful. Take her instead.”

3.verse: But Samson said to them, “This time ·no one will blame me [I am justified/blameless/innocent] for hurting you Philistines!”

4.verse: So Samson went out and caught three hundred ·foxes [or jackals]. He took two at a time, tied their tails together, and then tied a torch to the tails of each pair of ·foxes [or jackals].

5.verse: After he lit the torches, he let the ·foxes [or jackals] loose in the grainfields of the Philistines so that he burned up their standing grain, the ·piles [heaps; shocks] of grain, their vineyards, and their olive trees.

6.verse: The Philistines asked, “Who did this?” Someone told them, “Samson, the son-in-law of the ·man from Timnah [Timnite], did because his father-in-law gave his wife to his ·best man [companion].” So the Philistines burned Samson’s wife and her father to death.

7.verse: Then Samson said to the Philistines, “Since you did this, I won’t stop until I ·pay you back [get revenge on you]!”

8.verse: Samson ·attacked the Philistines and killed many of them [struck them down calf on thigh with a great slaughter]. Then he went down and stayed in a cave in the rock of Etam.

9.verse: The Philistines went up and camped in the land of Judah, ·near a place named [spreading out near; or overrunning/raiding] Lehi.

10.verse: The men of Judah asked them, “Why have you come here to fight us?” They answered, “We have come to make Samson our prisoner, to ·pay him back for what he did to our people [do to him as he did to us].”

11.verse: Then three thousand men of Judah went to the ·cave [cleft] in the rock of Etam and said to Samson, “What have you done to us? Don’t you know that the Philistines rule over us?” Samson answered, “I only ·paid them back for [did to them] what they did to me.”

12.verse: Then they said to him, “We have come to ·tie you up [bind you] and to hand you over to the Philistines.” Samson said to them, “Promise me you will not ·hurt [attack; come against] me yourselves.”

13.verse: The men from Judah said, “·We agree [No; meaning they wouldn’t hurt him]. We will just ·tie you up [bind you] and give you to the Philistines. We will not kill you.” So they tied Samson with two new ropes and led him up from the cave in the rock.

14.verse: When Samson came to the Lehi, the Philistines came to meet him, ·shouting for joy [or with shouts of triumph; shouting]. Then the Spirit of the LORD ·entered Samson and gave him great power [came upon/rushed upon/empowered him; 14:19]. The ropes on him weakened like burned ·strings [flax] and [his bonds] fell off his hands!

15.verse: Samson found the ·jawbone [fresh jawbone; not yet decayed] of a ·dead donkey [ass], took it, and ·killed [struck down] a thousand men with it!

16.verse: Then Samson said, “With a donkey’s jawbone I ·made donkeys out of them [or have piled them in heaps]. With a donkey’s jawbone I ·killed [struck down] a thousand men!”

17.verse: When he finished speaking, he threw away the jawbone. So that place was named Ramath Lehi [Jawbone Hill].

18.verse: Samson was very thirsty, so he cried out to the LORD, “You gave me, your servant, this great victory. Do I have to die of thirst now? Do I have to be captured by ·people who are not circumcised [or these pagans; the uncircumcised]?”

19.verse: Then God ·opened up a hole in the ground [split open the basin/hollow place] at Lehi, and water came out. When Samson drank, his strength returned and he ·felt better [revived]. So he named that spring ·Caller’s Spring [or Spring of the One Who Cries Out; En Hakkore], which is still in Lehi.

20.verse: Samson ·judged [led] Israel for twenty years in the days of the Philistines.

1.verse: Samson Goes to the City of Gaza - One day Samson went to Gaza and saw a prostitute there. He went in ·to spend the night with her [to her; a euphemism for sexual relations].

2.verse: When the people of Gaza heard, “Samson has come here!” they surrounded the place and ·waited for him [set an ambush; lay in wait] near the city gate all night. They whispered to each other, “·When dawn comes [At the morning light], we will kill Samson!”

3.verse: But Samson only stayed with the prostitute until midnight. Then he got up and took hold of the doors and the two posts of the city gate and tore them loose, along with the bar. He put them on his shoulders and carried them to the top of the hill that faces the city of Hebron.

4.verse: Samson and Delilah - After this, Samson fell in love with a woman named Delilah, who lived in the Valley of Sorek.

5.verse: The Philistine ·rulers [lords] went to Delilah and said, “Find out what makes Samson so strong. ·Trick [Seduce; Entice] him into telling you how we can overpower him and tie him up and ·capture [subdue] him. If you do this, each one of us will give you ·twenty-eight pounds [eleven hundred pieces] of silver.”

6.verse: So Delilah said to Samson, “Tell me why you are so strong. How can someone tie you up and ·capture [subdue] you?”

7.verse: Samson answered, “Someone would have to tie me up with seven ·new [fresh] bowstrings that have not been dried. Then I would be as weak as any other man.”

8.verse: The Philistine ·rulers [lords] brought Delilah seven ·new [fresh] bowstrings that had not been dried, and she tied Samson with them.

9.verse: Some men were ·hiding [lying in wait] in ·another [an inner; or their] room. Delilah said to him, “Samson, the Philistines are here!” But Samson broke the bowstrings like pieces of burned ·string [flax]. So the Philistines did not find out the secret of Samson’s strength.

10.verse: Then Delilah said to Samson, “You ·made a fool of [mocked; or deceived] me. You lied to me. Now tell me how someone can ·tie you up [subdue you].”

11.verse: Samson said, “They would have to tie me with new ropes that have not been used before. Then I would become as weak as any other man.”

12.verse: So Delilah took new ropes and tied Samson. Some men were hiding in ·another [an inner; or their] room. She called out to him, “Samson, the Philistines are here!” But he broke the ropes from his arms as easily as if they were threads.

13.verse: Then Delilah said to Samson, “·Again [Until now] you have ·made a fool of [mocked; or deceived] me. You lied to me. Tell me how someone can tie you up.” He said, “Using the loom, weave the seven braids of my hair into the ·cloth [woven fabric; web], and tighten it with a pin. Then I will be as weak as any other man.” While Samson slept, Delilah wove the seven braids of his hair into the ·cloth [woven fabric; web].

14.verse: Then she fastened it with a pin. Again she said to him, “Samson, the Philistines are here!” Samson woke up and pulled out the pin and the loom with the ·cloth [woven fabric; web].

15.verse: Then Delilah said to him, “How can you say, ‘I love you,’ when ·you don’t even trust me [your heart is not with me]? This is the third time you have ·made a fool of [mocked; or deceived] me. You haven’t told me the secret of your great strength.”

16.verse: She ·kept bothering [nagged; pressed] Samson about his secret day after day until ·he felt he was going to die [his soul was annoyed to death]!

17.verse: So he told her ·everything [all his heart]. He said, “·I have never had my hair cut [A razor has never come upon my head], because I have been set apart to God as a Nazirite ·since I was born [from my mother’s womb; 13:5, 7; Num. 6:1–12]. If someone shaved my head, I would lose my strength and be as weak as any other man.”

18.verse: When Delilah saw that he had told her ·everything sincerely [all his heart], she sent a message to the Philistine ·rulers [lords]. She said, “Come back one more time, because he has told me ·everything [all that is in his heart].” So the Philistine rulers came back to Delilah and brought the silver ·with them [in their hands].

19.verse: Delilah got Samson to sleep, lying in her lap. Then she called in a man to shave off the seven braids of Samson’s hair. In this way she began to ·make him weak [subdue him; make him vulnerable], and his strength left him.

20.verse: Then she said, “Samson, the Philistines are here!” He woke up and thought, “I’ll leave as I did before and shake myself free.” But he did not know that the LORD had left him.

21.verse: Then the Philistines captured Samson and ·tore [gouged] out his eyes. They took him down to Gaza, where they put bronze ·chains [shackles] on him and made him grind grain in the prison.

22.verse: But his hair began to grow again after it was shaved off.

23.verse: Samson Dies - The Philistine ·rulers [lords] gathered to celebrate and to offer a great sacrifice to their god Dagon. They said, “Our god has handed Samson our enemy ·over to us [into our hand].”

24.verse: When the people saw him, they praised their god, saying, “This man ·destroyed [laid waste; ravaged] our country. He ·killed many of us [multiplied our dead]! But our god handed over our enemy to us.”

25.verse: ·While the people were enjoying the celebration [When they were in high spirits; When their heart was good], they said, “Bring Samson out to ·perform for [entertain; amuse] us.” So they brought Samson from the prison, and he ·performed for [entertained; amused] them. They made him stand between the pillars.

26.verse: Samson said to the ·servant [youth; young man] holding his hand, “Let me feel the pillars that hold up the ·temple [house] so I can lean against them.”

27.verse: Now the ·temple [house] was full of men and women. All the Philistine ·rulers [lords] were there, and about three thousand men and women were on the roof watching Samson perform.

28.verse: Then Samson prayed to the LORD, “·Lord GOD [Sovereign LORD], remember me. God, please give me strength one more time so I ·can pay these Philistines back [avenge the Philistines] for putting out my two eyes!”

29.verse: Then Samson ·turned to [grasped] the two center pillars ·that supported the whole temple [on which the house rested]. He braced himself between the two pillars, with his right hand on one and his left hand on the other.

30.verse: Samson said, “Let me die with these Philistines!” Then he pushed ·as hard as he could [with all his strength], causing the temple to fall on the ·rulers [lords] and all the people in it. So Samson killed more of the Philistines when he died than ·when he was alive [during his lifetime].

31.verse: Samson’s brothers and ·his whole family [all the house of his father] went down to get his body. They brought him back and buried him in the tomb of Manoah, his father, between the cities of Zorah and Eshtaol. Samson had ·judged [led; 2:16] Israel for twenty years.

1.verse: Micah’s Idols - There was a man named Micah who lived in the ·mountains [hill country] of Ephraim.

2.verse: He said to his mother, “I heard you speak a curse [uttered against the thief] about the ·twenty-eight pounds [eleven hundred pieces] of silver that were taken from you. I have the silver with me; I took it.” His mother said, “The LORD bless you, my son [for confessing the crime]!”

3.verse: Micah gave the ·twenty-eight pounds [eleven hundred pieces] of silver to his mother. Then she said, “I will ·give [dedicate] this silver [from my hand] to the LORD. ·I will have my son make [or For the benefit of my son I will make] ·an idol and a statue [a carved image and a cast-metal image; or a carved image overlaid with silver]. So I will give the silver back to you.”

4.verse: When he gave the silver back to his mother, she took about ·five pounds [two hundred pieces of silver] and gave it to a ·silversmith [or idol-maker; Acts 19:24]. With it he made an ·idol and a statue [or carved image overlaid with silver; an abomination and violation of the law; Deut. 27:15], which stood in Micah’s house.

5.verse: Micah had a ·special holy place [shrine], and he made a ·holy vest [ephod] and some ·household idols [teraphim; Gen. 31:19]. Then Micah ·chose [ordained; installed; or paid; filled the hand of] one of his sons to be his priest.

6.verse: At that time Israel did not have a king, so everyone did what seemed right in their own eyes [the common refrain through the rest of Judges, referring both to the lack of a human king and the rejection of God’s sovereignty; 18:1; 19:1; 21:25].

7.verse: There was a young man who was a Levite [the priestly tribe of Israel; Num. 1:47–53] from the city of Bethlehem in Judah who was ·from [or living among] the people of Judah.

8.verse: He left Bethlehem to look for another place to live, and ·on his way [or to carry on his vocation] he came to Micah’s house in the ·mountains [hill country] of Ephraim.

9.verse: Micah asked him, “Where are you from?” He answered, “I’m a Levite from Bethlehem in Judah. I’m looking for a place to live.”

10.verse: Micah said to him, “Live with me and be my father [meaning an advisor or counselor; Gen. 45:8] and my priest. I will give you ·four ounces [ten pieces] of silver each year and clothes and food.” So the Levite went in.

11.verse: He agreed to live with Micah and became like one of Micah’s own sons.

12.verse: Micah ·made him [installed/ordained him as; or paid him to be; filled his hand to be] a priest, and he lived in Micah’s house.

13.verse: Then Micah said, “Now I know the LORD will ·be good to [prosper] me, because I have a Levite as my priest.”

1.verse: The Tribe of Dan Captures Laish - At that time Israel did not have a king [17:6]. And at that time the tribe of Dan was still ·looking for a land [seeking an inheritance] where they could live, a land of their own. The Danites had not yet ·been given their own land [moved into their land; received their allotment] among the tribes of Israel.

2.verse: So, from their family groups, they chose five ·soldiers [valiant men; men, sons of strength] from the cities of Zorah and Eshtaol to spy out and explore the land. They were told, “Go, explore the land.” They came to the ·mountains [hill country] of Ephraim, to Micah’s house, where they spent the night.

3.verse: When they came near Micah’s house, they recognized the ·voice [or accent] of the young Levite [17:7]. So they stopped there and asked him, “Who brought you here? What are you doing here? ·Why are you here [What is your business here]?”

4.verse: He told them what Micah had done for him, saying, “He hired me. I am his priest.”

5.verse: They said to him, “Please ask God if ·our journey [our mission; the way we are going] will be successful.”

6.verse: The priest said to them, “Go in peace. The LORD ·is pleased with [approves of; watches over] your journey.”

7.verse: So the five men left. When they came to the city of Laish, they saw that the people there lived in safety, ·like [according to the custom of] the people of Sidon. They ·thought they were safe [were quiet and secure/unsuspecting] and ·had plenty of everything [or no ruler was humiliating them]. They lived a long way from the Sidonians and had no dealings with anyone else.

8.verse: When the five men returned to Zorah and Eshtaol, their ·relatives [brothers] asked them, “What did you find?”

9.verse: They answered, “We have seen the land, and it is very good. ·We should attack [Arise, let us go up against] them. ·Aren’t you going to do something [Are you just going to sit there]? Don’t ·wait [hesitate; or be lazy]! Let’s go and take that land!

10.verse: When you go, you will see there is ·plenty of [a wide/spacious] land—·plenty of everything [lacking nothing]! The people are not expecting an attack. Surely God has handed that land over to us!”

11.verse: So six hundred Danites left Zorah and Eshtaol ·ready for [armed with weapons of] war.

12.verse: On their way they set up camp near the city of Kiriath Jearim in Judah. That is why the place west of Kiriath Jearim is named Mahaneh Dan [“Camp of Dan”] to this day.

13.verse: From there they traveled on to the ·mountains [hill country] of Ephraim. Then they came to Micah’s house.

14.verse: The five men who had explored the land around Laish said to their ·relatives [brothers], “Do you know in one of these houses there are a ·holy vest [ephod; Ex. 28:6–14], household gods [17:5], an ·idol, and a statue [or image overlaid with silver; 17:3]? ·You know [or Decide now] what to do.”

15.verse: So they stopped at the Levite’s house, which was also Micah’s house, and ·greeted the Levite [or asked how he was doing].

16.verse: The six hundred ·Danites [men who were of the sons/descendants of Dan] stood at the entrance gate, wearing their weapons of war.

17.verse: The five spies went into the house and took the ·idol [carved image], the ·holy vest [ephod], the household idols, and the ·statue [cast-metal image]. The priest and the six hundred men armed ·for [with weapons of] war stood by the entrance gate.

18.verse: When the spies went into Micah’s house and took the [carved] image, the ·holy vest [ephod], the household idols, and the ·statue [cast-metal image], the priest asked them, “What are you doing?”

19.verse: They answered, “Be quiet! ·Don’t say a word [Put your hand over your mouth]. Come with us and be our father [meaning an advisor or counselor; 17:10; Gen. 45:8] and priest. Is it better for you to be a priest for one man’s house or for a tribe and ·family group [clan] in Israel?”

20.verse: This ·made the priest happy [pleased the heart of the priest]. So he took the ·holy vest [ephod], the household idols [17:5], and the ·idol [carved image] and went with the ·Danites [people].

21.verse: They left Micah’s house, putting their little children, their animals, and everything they owned in front of them [for protection in case of attack; Gen. 33:2–3].

22.verse: When they had gone a little way from Micah’s house, the men who lived near Micah ·were called out [assembled] and caught up with them.

23.verse: The men with Micah shouted at the ·Danites [sons/descendants of Dan], who turned around and said to Micah, “What’s the matter with you? Why have you ·been called out to [assembled for a] fight?”

24.verse: Micah answered, “You took my gods that I made and my priest. What do I have left? How can you ask me, ‘What’s the matter?’”

25.verse: The ·Danites [sons/descendants of Dan] answered, “·You should not argue with [or Don’t say another word to; Don’t let your voice be heard among] us. Some of our ·angry [bitter] men might attack you, ·killing you [and you will lose your life] and your ·family [household].”

26.verse: Then the ·Danites [sons/descendants of Dan] went on their way. Micah knew they were too strong for him, so he turned and went back home.

27.verse: Then the Danites took what Micah had made and his priest and went on to Laish. They attacked those ·peaceful [quiet] and ·unsuspecting [secure] people and killed them with their swords and then burned the city.

28.verse: There was no one to ·save [rescue; deliver] the people of Laish. They lived too far from Sidon, and they had no dealings with anyone else. Laish was in a valley near Beth Rehob. The people of Dan rebuilt the city and lived there.

29.verse: They named the city Dan after their ancestor Dan, one of the sons of Israel; the city’s original name was Laish.

30.verse: The ·people [sons; descendants] of Dan set up the ·idol [carved image] in the city of Dan. Jonathan son of Gershom, Moses’ son, and his sons served as priests for the tribe of Dan until the ·land was captured [captivity of the land; time of the exile].

31.verse: The people of Dan set up the ·idols [carved images] Micah had made as long as the ·Holy Tent [Tabernacle; House] of God was in Shiloh.

1.verse: A Levite and His Servant - At that time Israel did not have a king [17:6]. There was a Levite who lived in the ·faraway [remote] ·mountains [hill country] of Ephraim. He had taken a ·slave woman [concubine; 8:31] from the city of Bethlehem in the land of Judah to live with him,

2.verse: but she ·was unfaithful to [or became angry with] him. She left him and went back to her father’s house in Bethlehem in Judah and stayed there for four months.

3.verse: Then her husband went to ·ask her [persuade her; speak to her heart] to come back to him, taking with him his servant and two donkeys. When the Levite came to her father’s house, she invited him to come in, and her father was happy to ·see [welcome; meet] him.

4.verse: The father-in-law, the young woman’s father, ·asked [urged; persuaded] him to stay. So he stayed for three days and ate, drank, and slept there [hospitality was (and is) a very high cultural value in the Middle East].

5.verse: On the fourth day they got up early in the morning. The Levite was getting ready to leave, but the woman’s father said to his son-in-law, “·Refresh [Strengthen] yourself by eating something. Then go.”

6.verse: So the two men sat down to eat and drink together. After that, the father said to him, “Please stay tonight. Relax and enjoy yourself.”

7.verse: When the man got up to go, his father-in-law ·asked [urged; persuaded] him to stay. So he stayed again that night.

8.verse: On the fifth day the man got up early in the morning to leave. The woman’s father said, “·Refresh [Strengthen] yourself. Wait until this afternoon.” So the two men ate together.

9.verse: When the Levite, his ·slave woman [concubine; v. 1], and his servant got up to leave, the father-in-law, the young woman’s father, said, “It’s almost night. The day is almost gone. Spend the night here and enjoy yourself. Tomorrow morning you can get up early and go home.”

10.verse: But the Levite did not want to stay another night. So he took his two saddled donkeys and his ·slave woman [concubine] and ·traveled toward [arose and went and came opposite] the city of Jebus (also called Jerusalem).

11.verse: As the day was almost over, they came near Jebus. So the servant said to his master, “Let’s stop at this city of the Jebusites, and spend the night here.”

12.verse: But his master said, “No. We won’t go inside a foreign city. Those people are not ·Israelites [of the sons/children of Israel]. We will go on to the city of Gibeah.”

13.verse: He said, “Come on. Let’s try to make it to Gibeah or Ramah so we can spend the night in one of those cities.”

14.verse: So they went on. The sun went down as they came near Gibeah, which belongs to the tribe of Benjamin.

15.verse: They stopped there to spend the night. They came to the public square [an open area inside the city gate, the hub for business, government, and social interaction] of the city and sat down, but no one invited them home to spend the night [a mark of shame for the city, since hospitality was of great importance; contrast this with vv. 3–9].

16.verse: Finally, in the evening an old man came in from his work in the fields. His home was in the ·mountains [hill country] of Ephraim, but now he was ·living [residing; staying] in Gibeah. (The people of Gibeah were from the tribe of Benjamin.)

17.verse: He saw the traveler in the public square and asked, “Where are you going? Where did you come from?”

18.verse: The Levite answered, “We are traveling from Bethlehem in Judah to my home in a remote area of the ·mountains [hill country] of Ephraim. I have been to Bethlehem in Judah, but now I am going to the ·Holy Tent [House] of the LORD [probably the shrine at Shiloh; 18:31; Josh. 18:1]. No one has invited me to stay in his house.

19.verse: We already have straw and food for our donkeys and bread and wine for me, ·the young woman [your maidservant], and my ·servant [the young man with your servants; politely referring to himself and his servants as the old man’s servants]. We don’t need anything.”

20.verse: The old man said, “You are welcome to stay at my house. Let me give you anything you need, but don’t spend the night in the public square.”

21.verse: So the old man took the Levite into his house, and he fed their donkeys. They washed their feet and had something to eat and drink.

22.verse: While they were enjoying themselves, [look; behold] some ·wicked [worthless; troublemaking] men of the city surrounded the house and beat on the door. They shouted to the old man who owned the house, “Bring out the man who came to your house. We want to ·have sexual relations with [know; a euphemism for sex] him.” [The Benjamites had become as evil as the men of Sodom; Gen. 19:1–11.]

23.verse: The owner of the house went outside and said to them, “No, my ·friends [brothers]. Don’t be so evil. This man is a guest in my house. Don’t do this ·terrible [outrageous; disgraceful; vile] thing!

24.verse: Look, here are my ·daughter, who has never had sexual relations before [virgin daughter], and the man’s ·slave woman [concubine; v. 1]. I will bring them out to you now. You can ·abuse [violate] them and do ·anything you want [what is good in your eyes] with them, but don’t do such a ·terrible [outrageous; disgraceful; vile] thing to this man.”

25.verse: But the men would not listen to him. So the Levite took his ·slave woman [concubine; v. 1] and sent her outside to them. They ·forced her to have sexual relations with them [raped her], and they abused her all night long. Then, at dawn, they let her go.

26.verse: She came back to the house where her master was staying and fell down at the door and lay there until daylight.

27.verse: In the morning when the Levite got up, he opened the door of the house and went outside to go on his way. But his slave woman was lying at the doorway of the house, with her hands on the ·doorsill [threshold].

28.verse: The Levite said to her, “Get up; let’s go.” But she did not answer. So he put her on his donkey and went home.

29.verse: When the Levite got home, he took a knife and cut his ·slave woman [concubine; v. 1] into twelve parts, limb by limb. Then he sent a part to each area of Israel.

30.verse: Everyone who saw this said, “Nothing like this has ever happened before, not since the ·people [sons; children] of Israel came out of Egypt. Think about it [Consider this; or Just imagine!]. Discuss it [Take counsel; or Make a plan]. Tell us what to do [or Speak out against this!].”

1.verse: The War Between Israel and Benjamin - So all the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] from Dan to Beersheba [from the farthest north to the farthest south], including the land of Gilead [on the east side of the Jordan River], ·joined together [assembled] before the LORD in the city of Mizpah.

2.verse: The ·leaders [cornerstones; Is. 19:13] of all the tribes of Israel took their places in the ·meeting [assembly] of the people of God. There were 400,000 soldiers ·with swords [who drew the sword].

3.verse: (The ·people [sons; descendants] of Benjamin heard that the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] had gone up to Mizpah.) Then the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] said to the Levite, “Tell us how this evil thing happened.”

4.verse: So the husband of the murdered woman answered, “My ·slave woman [concubine; 8:31] and I came to Gibeah in Benjamin to spend the night.

5.verse: During the night the ·men [leaders; lords] of Gibeah came after me. They surrounded the house and wanted to kill me. They ·forced my slave woman to have sexual relations [abused/raped my concubine] and she died.

6.verse: I took her and cut her into parts and sent ·one part [her] to ·each area [every region of the inheritance] of Israel because the people of Benjamin did this ·wicked [lewd; abominable] and ·terrible [outrageous; shameful] thing in Israel.

7.verse: Now, all you ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel], speak up. What is your decision?”

8.verse: Then all the people stood up at the same time, saying, “None of us will go ·home [to his tent]. Not one of us will go back to his house!

9.verse: Now this is what we will do to Gibeah. We will ·throw lots [go against it by lot].

10.verse: That way we will choose ten men from every hundred men from all the tribes of Israel, and we will choose a hundred men from every thousand, and a thousand men from every ten thousand. These will find ·supplies [provisions; food] for the army. Then the army will go to the city of Gibeah of Benjamin to ·repay [punish] them for the ·terrible [outrageous; shameful] thing they have done in Israel.”

11.verse: So all the men of Israel were united and gathered against the city.

12.verse: The tribes of Israel sent men throughout the tribe of Benjamin demanding, “What is this ·evil [wicked; terrible] thing ·some of your men have done [that has taken place among you]?

13.verse: Hand over the ·wicked [worthless; troublemaking] men in Gibeah so that we can put them to death. We must ·remove [purge] this evil from Israel.” But the ·Benjaminites [sons of Benjamin] would not listen to their ·fellow Israelites [brothers, the sons of Israel].

14.verse: The ·Benjaminites [sons of Benjamin] left their own cities and met at Gibeah to fight the Israelites.

15.verse: In only one day the ·Benjaminites [sons of Benjamin] ·got [mobilized; mustered] 26,000 soldiers together who ·were trained with swords [drew the sword]. They also had 700 ·chosen [elite; well-trained] men from Gibeah.

16.verse: Among all these trained soldiers, seven hundred were left-handed [3:15], each of whom could sling a stone at a hair and not miss [1 Sam. 17:49]!

17.verse: The Israelites, except for the Benjaminites, gathered 400,000 ·soldiers with swords [men who drew the sword, all of them men of war].

18.verse: The ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] went up to the ·city of Bethel [or house of God; the meaning of the name “Bethel”] and asked God, “·Which tribe [Who] shall be first to attack the Benjaminites?” The LORD answered, “Judah shall go first.”

19.verse: The next morning the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] got up and ·made a camp near [or encamped against] Gibeah.

20.verse: The men of Israel went out to fight the Benjaminites and took their battle position at Gibeah.

21.verse: Then the ·Benjaminites [sons/descendants of Benjamin] came out of Gibeah and killed 22,000 Israelites during the battle that day.

22.verse: The ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] went before the LORD and cried until evening. They asked the LORD, “Shall we go to fight ·our relatives, the Benjaminites [the sons of my brother Benjamin], again?” The LORD answered, “Go up and fight them.” The men of Israel encouraged each other. So they took the same battle positions they had taken the first day.

23.verse: The ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] went before the LORD and cried until evening. They asked the LORD, “Shall we go to fight ·our relatives, the Benjaminites [the sons of my brother Benjamin], again?” The LORD answered, “Go up and fight them.” The men of Israel encouraged each other. So they took the same battle positions they had taken the first day.

24.verse: The ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] ·came to fight [drew near to] the ·Benjaminites [sons/descendants of Benjamin] the second day.

25.verse: The Benjaminites came out of Gibeah to attack the Israelites. This time, the Benjaminites killed 18,000 ·Israelites [men of the sons/children of Israel], all of whom ·carried swords [drew the sword].

26.verse: Then all the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel], the whole army, went up to Bethel [v. 18]. There they sat down and cried to the LORD and fasted all day until evening. They also brought burnt offerings and ·fellowship [or peace] offerings to the LORD.

27.verse: The ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] asked the LORD a question. (In those days the Ark of the ·Agreement with God [Covenant; Treaty] was there.

28.verse: A priest named Phinehas son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron, served before ·the Ark of the Agreement [it].) They asked, “Shall ·we [I] go to fight ·our relatives [my brother], the Benjaminites, again, or shall we stop fighting?” The LORD answered, “Go, because tomorrow I will ·hand them over to you [give them into your hand].”

29.verse: Then the Israelites set up ambushes all around Gibeah.

30.verse: They went to fight against the Benjaminites at Gibeah on the third day, getting into position for battle as they had done before.

31.verse: When the Benjaminites came out to fight them, the ·Israelites [people] backed up and drew them away from the city. The ·Benjaminites [sons/descendants of Benjamin] began to kill some of the ·Israelites [people] as they had done before. About thirty Israelites were killed—some in the fields and some on the roads leading to Bethel and to Gibeah.

32.verse: The ·Benjaminites [sons/descendants of Benjamin] said, “We are winning as before!” But the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] said, “Let’s ·run [retreat; flee]. Let’s ·trick them into going farther away [draw/lure them away] from their city and onto the roads.”

33.verse: All the Israelites moved from their places and got into battle positions at a place named Baal Tamar. Then the Israelites ·ran out [charged; jumped up] from their hiding places ·west of Gibeah [or from Maareh-geba].

34.verse: Ten thousand of the ·best trained [elite; chosen] soldiers from all of Israel attacked Gibeah. The battle was very hard. The Benjaminites did not know disaster was ·about to come to them [close at hand; touching against them].

35.verse: The LORD ·used the Israelites to defeat the Benjaminites [struck Benjamin in front of Israel]. On that day the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] killed 25,100 Benjaminites, ·all armed with swords [who drew the sword].

36.verse: Then the ·Benjaminites [sons/descendants of Benjamin] saw that they were defeated. The Israelites had ·moved back [retreated] because they were depending on the ·surprise attack [ambush] they had set up near Gibeah [verses 36b–45 now detail the account summarized in verses 29–36a)].

37.verse: The men in ·hiding [ambush] rushed into Gibeah, spread out, and killed everyone in the city with ·their swords [the edge of the sword].

38.verse: Now the Israelites had set up a signal with the men in hiding. The men in the ·surprise attack [ambush] were to send up a cloud of smoke from the city.

39.verse: Then the army of Israel ·turned around in the battle [counterattacked; a similar strategy was used against Ai; Josh. 8]. The Benjaminites had killed about thirty Israelites. They were saying, “·We are winning [They are defeated], as in the first battle!”

40.verse: But then a cloud of smoke began to rise from the city. The Benjaminites turned around and ·saw that [look; behold] the whole city was going up ·in smoke [into the sky/heavens].

41.verse: Then the Israelites turned and began to fight. The Benjaminites were terrified because they knew that disaster was ·coming to them [close at hand; touching against them].

42.verse: So the Benjaminites ran away from the Israelites toward the ·desert [wilderness], but ·they could not escape the battle [the battle pursued/overtook them]. And the Israelites who came out of the cities ·killed [struck; destroyed] them.

43.verse: They surrounded the Benjaminites and chased them and ·caught [overtook; stomped on] them in the area east of ·Gibeah [or Geba].

44.verse: So 18,000 ·brave [valiant; capable] Benjaminite fighters were killed.

45.verse: The Benjaminites ·ran [fled; retreated] toward the ·desert [wilderness] to the rock of Rimmon, but the Israelites ·killed [cut down; gleaned] 5,000 Benjaminites along the roads. They chased them as far as Gidom and ·killed [struck down] 2,000 more Benjaminites there.

46.verse: On that day 25,000 Benjaminites were killed, ·all of whom had fought bravely with swords [valiant/capable men who drew the sword].

47.verse: But 600 Benjaminites ran to the rock of Rimmon in the ·desert [wilderness], where they stayed for four months.

48.verse: Then the Israelites went back to the ·land [sons] of Benjamin and killed the people in every city and also the animals and everything they could find. And they burned every city they ·found [came to].

1.verse: Wives for the Men of Benjamin - At Mizpah the men of Israel had sworn, “Not one of us will let his daughter marry a man from the tribe of Benjamin.”

2.verse: The people went to the city of Bethel and sat before God until evening, ·crying loudly [lifting their voices weeping greatly].

3.verse: They said, “LORD, God of Israel, why has this terrible thing happened to us so that one tribe ·of Israel is missing [has disappeared from Israel] today?”

4.verse: Early the next day the people built an altar and put burnt offerings [Lev. 1:1–17] and ·fellowship [or peace; well-being] offerings [Lev. 3:1] to God on it.

5.verse: Then the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] asked, “Did any tribe of Israel not ·come here to meet [assemble] with us ·in the presence of [before] the LORD?” They asked this question because they had ·sworn [taken a solemn oath] that anyone who did not meet with them at Mizpah would be ·killed [put to death].

6.verse: The ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] felt sorry for ·their relatives, the Benjaminites [Benjamin, their brother]. They said, “Today one tribe has been cut off from Israel.

7.verse: We swore before the LORD that we would not ·allow our daughters to marry a Benjaminite [give our daughters to them for wives]. How can we make sure that the remaining men of Benjamin will have wives?”

8.verse: Then they asked, “Which one of the tribes of Israel did not ·meet with us [assemble] ·in the presence of [before] the LORD at Mizpah?” ·They found that [And look/behold] no one from the city of Jabesh Gilead had come.

9.verse: The people of Israel counted everyone, but there was no one from Jabesh Gilead.

10.verse: So the ·whole group of Israelites [assembly; congregation] sent twelve thousand ·soldiers [men, sons of strength] to Jabesh Gilead to kill the people with ·their swords [the edge of the sword], even the women and children.

11.verse: “This is what you must do: Kill every man in Jabesh Gilead and every ·married woman [woman who has known the bed of a male].”

12.verse: The soldiers found four hundred young ·unmarried women [virgins; Num. 31:17–18] among the residents of Jabesh Gilead, so they brought them to the camp at Shiloh in the land of Canaan.

13.verse: Then the whole ·group of Israelites [assembly; congregation] sent a message to the ·men [sons; descendants] of Benjamin, who were at the rock of Rimmon, ·offering to make peace with [calling/proclaiming peace to] them.

14.verse: So the men of Benjamin came back at that time. The Israelites gave them the women from Jabesh Gilead who had ·not been killed [been spared/kept alive], but there were not enough women.

15.verse: The people of Israel ·felt sorry [had compassion; grieved] for the Benjaminites because the LORD had ·separated [made a gap/breach in] the tribes of Israel.

16.verse: The elders of the ·Israelites [assembly; congregation] said, “The women of Benjamin have been ·killed [destroyed; wiped out]. ·Where can we get wives [What shall we do] for the men of Benjamin who are still alive?

17.verse: ·These men must have children to continue their families [The survivors of Benjamin must have heirs/an inheritance] so a tribe in Israel will not ·die [be wiped/blotted] out.

18.verse: But we cannot allow our daughters to marry them, because ·we swore [the sons/children of Israel had sworn], ‘Anyone who gives a wife to ·a man of Benjamin [Benjamin] is cursed.’

19.verse: ·We have an idea [Look; Behold]! There is a yearly festival of the LORD at Shiloh, which is north of the city of Bethel, east of the road that goes from Bethel to Shechem, and south of the city of Lebonah.”

20.verse: So ·the elders [they] told the men of Benjamin, “Go and ·hide [lie in wait/ambush] in the vineyards.

21.verse: Watch for the young women from Shiloh to come out to join the dancing. Then run out from the vineyards and ·take [seize; catch] ·one of the young Shiloh women [each man his wife from the daughters of Shiloh] and return to the land of Benjamin.

22.verse: ·If [or When] their fathers or brothers come to us and complain, we will say: ‘·Be kind to the men of Benjamin [or Do us a favor], because we did not get wives for Benjamin during the war. And you are not guilty [of breaking your oath; v. 18] because you did not [voluntarily] give the women to the men from Benjamin.’”

23.verse: So that is what the ·Benjaminites [sons/descendants of Benjamin] did. While the young women were dancing, each man caught one of them [according to their number], ·took her away, and married her [and carried her off]. Then they went back to ·the land God had given them [their inheritance] and rebuilt their cities and lived there.

24.verse: Then the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] went home to their own tribes and ·family groups [clans], to their own ·land that God had given them [inheritance].

25.verse: In those days Israel did not have a king. All the people did whatever seemed right in their own eyes [17:6; 18:1; 19:1].
